etymologies: Middle English: from Latin Mercurius (see Mercury (sense 2))

definitions: the chemical element of atomic number 80, a heavy silvery-white metal which is liquid at ordinary temperatures.

notes.text: The element mercury was regarded by alchemists as one of the five elementary principles of which all substances were supposed to be compounded. Its main ore is cinnabar. The main use of mercury is in batteries, switches, lamps, and other electrical equipment, and it is also used in thermometers and barometers, and in alloys (amalgams) with other metals

definitions: the column of mercury in a thermometer or barometer, or its height as indicating atmospheric temperature or pressure

examples.text: the mercury rises, the skies steam, and the nights swelter

shortDefinitions: column of mercury in thermometer or barometer

definitions: mercury or one of its compounds used medicinally, especially to treat syphilis

examples.text: one wonders how many unfortunates owed their demise to his prescription of mercury to clarify the spleen

shortDefinitions: mercury or one of its compounds used medicinally

etymologies: mid 16th century: from the genus name, from Latin mercurialis ‘of the god Mercury’

definitions: a plant of the spurge family.

notes.text: Genera Mercurialis and Acalypha, family Euphorbiaceae: several species, in particular the poisonous dog's mercury (M. perennis) of Eurasia and the three-seeded mercury (A. virginica) of North America

shortDefinitions: plant of genus which includes dog's mercury
